intro: Kalmia polifolia subsp. occidentalis, commonly known as the western mountain laurel, is a shrub native to the western United States. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its evergreen foliage. The plant produces showy, bell-shaped flowers that are typically pink or white, blooming in late spring to early summer. It thrives in acidic, well-drained soils and is often found in moist, shaded habitats such as forest understories. Its botanical features make it an important component of the ecological systems in its native range.
